Description

The issue and proposed fix was raised in the PR #27124, which was closed due to inaction.

I've opened this new one now to incorporate the suggested changes and add clarifying example and accompanying explanations.
items.title: fix(css): Clarify text and example for compund selectors with general sibling combinator (~)

items.content_html:
Fixes #28972, using the implementation in the report, which AFAICT is correct. Thank you, @andrewkazan!

Also removed a (to me) weird note about setting event handler properties.

This PR also needs the corresponding change in dom-examples: mdn/dom-examples#226 for a complete fix.
items.title: Fix issue 28972: correct fibonacci function

items.content_html:
Fixes #28997.

This is a much more extensive than I intended fix for #28997.

The main point of #28997 was that scroll is an inappropriate event to choose, because it's not cancellable (as the page itself already says). But also, the example showed a lot of feature-detection stuff, which I don't think is very relevant any more, and didn't show anything about the actual effect of the option.

So I have:

  • written a complete live sample showing the effect of setting passive on a wheel event
  • added it to "Examples" and linked it from the section that used to contain the not-useful example

All that is in commit 9b37e12.
Then I realized that this page contains two H2 sections, "Usage notes" and "Other notes", which seemed ridiculous, so I merged them in commit d2e114b. So that commit is really just moving stuff around.
items.title: Fix 28997: better example of passive listeners

items.content_html:
Description

This PR fixes various jsxref macro calls by:

  1. Removing the unnecessary Global_Objects slug prefix.
  2. Removing the slug where the slug can be inferred from the link text.
  3. Making the slug always a valid slug (e.g. Array.prototype.map => Array/map)

This results in overall terser code, demonstrating that jsxrefs are much more convenient than some people use it as, and are definitely more handy than Markdown links.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Make jsxref macro invocations terser

items.content_html:
Description

Add documentation for the memory.copy and memory.fill instructions to the WASM reference

Motivation

These were added by the bulk memory operations proposal. They are already in the spec:

The memory.fill instruction sets all values in a region to a given byte. The memory.copy instruction copies data from a source memory region to a possibly overlapping destination region.

Additional details

There was also a memory.fill instruction added, but I don't understand it well enough to document.

Related issues and pull requests

I didn't find anything related
items.title: Add WASM memory.copy and memory.fill docs

items.content_html:
The "Without nesting selector" section is confusing. The code shown here aims to show the impact of omitting the nesting selector (&). However, the section does not mention that the point being made applies to the old nesting spec--the two examples shown produce the same output with FireFox. To get the results shown you need be using Chrome or Safari (as of 12 September).

Description

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Clarify the nesting spec the example shows

items.content_html:
Description

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Caching#private_caches

has incorrect explanation about cache-control and authorization header.

Motivation

in Spec (RFC 9111) only mentions that if request contains Authorization header, it can't be stored in Shared Cache by default.

https://httpwg.org/specs/rfc9111.html#response.cacheability:~:text=if%20the%20cache%20is%20shared%3A%20the%20authorization%20header%20field%20is%20not%20present%20in%20the%20request%20(see%20section%2011.6.2%20of%20%5Bhttp%5D)

if the cache is shared: the Authorization header field is not present in the request (see Section 11.6.2 of [HTTP])

But the content mentions like below.

Note that if the response has an Authorization header, it cannot be stored in the private cache (or a shared cache, unless public is specified).

should remove private cache from here.

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #29019
items.title: fix wrong explanation about cache-control and authroization header

items.content_html:
FF118 aligns with spec and chrome in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1232918 to report the Windows and MacOS command key as "Meta" and key code as "MetaLeft" or "MetaRight" (depending on position). Previously "OS" and OSLeft/OSRight were returned.

This adds a release note.

Related work can be tracked in #28844
items.title: FF118 Relnote: Windows/Command key now referred to as Meta rather than OS

items.content_html:
Description

Fx118 introduces support for the from-font keyword in CSS font-size-adjust property.

Related issues and pull requests

Doc issue tracker: #28842
Bugzilla bug: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1708240
Content PR: #29052
items.title: docs(relnotes): Fx118 - Add release note for "from-font" in CSS "font-size-adjust"

items.content_html:
RTCPeerConnection.getTransceivers() returns only non-stopped transceivers according to https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1568296#c3. I tested this using the test in http://wpt.live/webrtc/RTCRtpTransceiver-stop.html with text "If a transceiver is stopped, transceivers, senders and receivers should disappear after offer/answer", which further indicates (as does the spec) that the receivers/senders are also removed. The test fails in 117 and passes in FF118.

This adds information to the transceiver, sender and receiver get methods.

Note that the first commit is layout only-ish. The second has the substantive changes.

Related to #28845
items.title: RTCPeerConnection.getTransceivers() doesn't return stopped transceivers

items.content_html:
Motivation

  • Fx118 adds support for the new keyword from-font for the font-size-adjust property (it is available in Firefox Nightly)
  • Spec: https://drafts.csswg.org/css-fonts-5/#font-size-adjust-prop
  • Updated syntax (already up-to-date in mdn/data):
    none | [ ex-height | cap-height | ch-width | ic-width | ic-height ]? [ from-font | <number [0,âˆž]>]

Summary of updates

  • Changes:

    • Edited the introductory paras
    • Moved some of the initial info and example to a new "Description" section
    • Written parts of the "Values" section to explain the new syntax and to add more clarity to the description of the values
    • Completely rewritten the <number [0,âˆž]> value, plus added an example

  • Additions:

    • Taking inspiration from the spec, added an example for "Determining the aspect value of a font"

Note: I have not yet been able to come up with a good example to show from-font - I would need two commonly used fonts with significant difference in aspect value and one missing a glyph that is available in the other.
The WPT test case for this feature uses the Ahem font to bring out the use case for from-font.

Known issue

"Formal syntax" in the font-size-adjust content page is not in sync with the numbered spec version. This is a known issue (#28900).

Related issues and pull requests

Doc issue tracker: #28842
Bugzilla bug: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1708240
items.title: docs(css): Fx118 - Document new keyword "from-font" for the "font-size-adjust" property

items.content_html:
Description

This PR adds content for multiple related features that go together to enable the creation of exit/entrance animations using simple CSS, or to put it another way, animating to/from display: none (this includes top layer elements like popovers), or animating elements when they have just been added to the DOM.

Specifically, these are:

  • @starting-style: Chrome 117
  • The overlay property: Chrome 117
  • Animating to/from display: none and content-visibility: hidden: Chrome 116
  • The transition-behavior property: Chrome 117

See my research document for more details of what this project aims to add.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: feat: Add content for overlay and discrete animation features

items.content_html:
Description

Added example for a WebSocket server in Deno.

Motivation

I was looking through the examples, and saw an example for a WebSocket server in C# and Java, but not for a JS backend. I wanted to provide an example for others where everything is in JS.

Additional details

Inspired by:

  • https://examples.deno.land/http-server-websocket

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Added WebSocket example for Deno

items.content_html:
For long the slice has been a source of confusion among developers. Apart from it's similarity with the splice in terms of name , I feel the naming of the parameters has also contributed. Also I had to specify what happens when we have negative arguments because clearly what happens with single negative arguments is different from what happens generally with the slice. Also naming our second parameter indexEnd is confusing because that particular index is not a part of it , as long as we counting from 0.

Description

Had to change parameter names and threw more light on negative indexes.

Motivation

The slice has been a source of confusion for so long and I think the parameter names and negative indexes contributed.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update index.md  indexEnd is not the end since we actually end before it
